column1: The retina captures light and converts it into electrical signals, which are sent to the brain for interpretation, allowing us to see.
A normal OCT scan shows a well-defined retinal structure with no fluid or deposits. Layers are smooth and continuous, with no signs of swelling or abnormal growth.
The macula is crucial for sharp, central vision, essential for tasks like reading and recognizing faces.
A healthy retina has well-defined layers, no fluid leakage or deposits, and healthy blood vessels. The macula and fovea are normal in shape and thickness.

Smoking, a poor diet, and lack of exercise can negatively impact retinal health.
Blurred vision, floaters, flashes of light, distorted vision, and a dark spot in your central vision can all indicate a retinal problem.

Omega-3 fatty acids support retinal blood vessel health and help prevent macular degeneration.
Vitamin C supports collagen production, which helps maintain the integrity of blood vessels in the retina, ensuring proper blood flow and nutrient delivery.
The retina's outer edges, beyond the macula, support peripheral vision, allowing you to see objects and movement in your side view.
Photoreceptors are light-sensitive cells in the retina that convert light into electrical signals, allowing us to see. They are essential for vision.
A family history of retinal diseases can increase your risk of developing similar conditions, even if you don't have symptoms yet.
